clinical_study.brief_title: Social Networks and Methadone Maintenance Treatment Retention and Antiretroviral Therapy Retention in Tanzania
clinical_study.official_title: Understanding the Role of Social Networks in Methadone Maintenance Treatment Retention and Antiretroviral Therapy Adherence Among People Who Inject Drugs in Tanzania

lead_sponsor.agency: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

collaborator.agency: Muhimbili University of Health and Allied Sciences

clinical_study.source: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

brief_summary.textblock: Investigators will adapt an existing social network intervention originally developed to support treatment-seeking people who use drugs in Baltimore, Maryland. This intervention draws from an alteration model of network change designed to change the structure and composition of the patient's social network that support treatment efforts. The intervention draws from Beckman's model of effective social networks by activating social support and influence, motivating social engagement, and enhancing access to community resources. Investigators will pilot test this one-month intervention with 25 HIV-positive patients enrolled in methadone maintenance treatment (MMT) and 25 identified community support persons (CSPs); one CSP per each participating MMT patient. The pilot will assess the social network intervention's acceptability and feasibility.

detailed_description.textblock:
Investigators will conduct a small pilot of the adapted social network intervention to assess its acceptability and feasibility. The study team will pilot the intervention with a total of 50 people: 25 HIV-positive patients enrolled in methadone maintenance treatment (MMT) and 25 community support persons (CSPs) identified by participating MMT patients. MMT patients and his/her CSP will complete a baseline survey on demographics, relationship to the patient/CSP, social network members, social support, engagement in social and/or recovery-oriented activities, and knowledge of and attitudes towards addiction/people with addiction, MMT and HIV. Participants will then attend one 2-hour group session each week for four weeks. Attendance will be documented for each group session. Group sessions will be facilitated by a community outreach worker or social worker affiliated with the study team using a manual adapted in a previous stage of the overall study.
Eligible MMT patients will identify a drug-free family member or friend (CSP) to attend weekly group sessions together. The CSP will learn methods to support and reinforce MMT retention and ART adherence. Through weekly "homework assignments," the CSP helps the patient engage in social, drug-free activities and connect to existing community resources (e.g. mutual-help groups, religious groups, sports groups, etc.) in efforts to expand the patient's recovery and treatment network.
At the end of the pilot, the study team will conduct a follow-up survey with MMT patient and CSP participants. The post- pilot survey will include similar questions to the baseline survey, but will also include questions to assess acceptability and satisfaction with group sessions, experiences attending social activities in the community with the MMT patient/CSP as part of "homework assignments," and suggestions for changes to the intervention.

primary_outcome.measure: Fidelity to the community support intervention group manual assessed by the Integrity of Group Intervention checklist
primary_outcome.time_frame: End of intervention (i.e. end of week 4)
primary_outcome.description: An Integrity of Group Intervention checklist will be created for the study to assess fidelity of the actual delivery of the intervention to intended delivery and content. Areas to be evaluated for fidelity will include: facilitator adherence to manual instructions, facilitator empathy, information and content covered in the session, competencies, and a global session score. Each item will be evaluated as "0" (did not meet the criterion) and "1" (did meet the criterion) by two trained raters. A total score will be calculated. A higher score will indicate better fidelity to the intervention manual.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of participants with high acceptability scores for intervention components post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: Acceptability of session contents, delivery and duration; Acceptability of "homework assignments," i.e. engagement in recovery-oriented community activities. The possible range for the total scale score will 0 to 4, with a higher score reflecting higher acceptability. Acceptability survey items will be included in the post-intervention survey.

secondary_outcome.description: Number of approved recovery-oriented community activities reported by MMT study participants with or without their designated CSP. This will be assessed by the Important People and Activities (IPA) instrument.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Currently enrolled in methadone maintenance treatment program or identified as supportive person by client currently enrolled in methadone maintenance treatment program
- Diagnosed with HIV (for clients currently enrolled in methadone maintenance treatment only) or aware of the HIV status of the person who referred them to the study (community support persons only)
- Available and able to participate weekly in group sessions
- Willing and able to provide informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Does not meet inclusion criteria

patient_data.ipd_description: This is pilot trial is intended for assessment of feasibility and acceptability. Study investigators will make aggregate data from the intervention trial available to other researchers. Aggregate data are unlikely to present an opportunity for secondary analysis or subsequent publication, though they can provide more detail than may be available in a peer-reviewed publication.
